document.title: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for Science

C80300C4F2934CAE83103DA5EADCF2CE.description: analyze past and present international treaties and protocols such as the environmental Antarctic Treaty System, Montreal Protocol, and Kyoto Protocol.

322054AE3A5C4682B158C02BFB4ACC16.description: analyze past and present local, state, and national legislation, including Texas automobile emissions regulations, the National Park Service Act, the Clean Air Act, the Clean Water Act, the Soil and Water Resources Conservation Act, and the Endangered Species Act;

A94F8DCFD8F9473EB80F102C420124B4.description: research the advantages and disadvantages of "going green" such as organic gardening and farming, natural methods of pest control, hydroponics, xeriscaping, energy-efficient homes and appliances, and hybrid cars;

65A95DE825134985BB0B45A79C95E9AD.description: discuss the impact of research and technology on social ethics and legal practices in situations such as the design of new buildings, recycling, or emission standards;

FAB8F949F2454C5D82D37AAD84C57794.description: analyze and evaluate different views on the existence of global warming;

48FC8F875F0A4C7FAD2F0F7DEF4124AD.description: analyze how ethical beliefs can be used to influence scientific practices such as methods for increasing food production;

295D3815315A40C1B7ACD0DBAF72F2D4.description: evaluate cost-benefit trade-offs of commercial activities such as municipal development, farming, deforestation, over-harvesting, and mining;

5BE20315CD2C4AF38DEF1C21CB3C710F.description: evaluate the effect of human activities, including habitat restoration projects, species preservation efforts, nature conservancy groups, hunting, fishing, ecotourism, all terrain vehicles, and small personal watercraft, on the environment;

4B2458946F1F4B4BBD94D9CF7A679525.description: describe the effect of pollution on global warming, glacial and ice cap melting, greenhouse effect, ozone layer, and aquatic viability;

18F068D7C4204F188D7125932A89A53B.description: examine the concentrations of air, soil, and water pollutants using appropriate units;

BEAE8F7CABF54DC6AF6DCE214608D589.description: investigate the types of air, soil, and water pollution such as chlorofluorocarbons, carbon dioxide, pH, pesticide runoff, thermal variations, metallic ions, heavy metals, and nuclear waste;

A5D00F6BC4CB4CB385725619301006E9.description: identify causes of air, soil, and water pollution, including point and nonpoint sources;

0940439C123A47AAB753FA2525F6A3E5.description: Science concepts. The student knows the impact of human activities on the environment. The student is expected to:

6C9C823730534A06926AB090E304BB6C.description: analyze the impact of temperature inversions on global warming, ice cap and glacial melting, and changes in ocean currents and surface temperatures.

2D7D604EEDA64383BBA610BFED990987.description: describe how temperature inversions impact weather conditions, including El Niño and La Niña oscillations;

C929EED4C3C64F6CB80DB3EE4AB27884.description: examine how natural processes such as succession and feedback loops restore habitats and ecosystems;

D855DCC346D64543A67B002FB949647A.description: explain how regional changes in the environment may have a global effect;

0A8F0A3606D3418EB2D8813FB6AC3E43.description: analyze and describe the effects on areas impacted by natural events such as tectonic movement, volcanic events, fires, tornadoes, hurricanes, flooding, tsunamis, and population growth;

74F84ECC65B54E07A71D9A304CB1E6C3.description: Science concepts. The student knows that environments change naturally. The student is expected to:

C932523CA837479CB463AA0B57DF83CE.description: analyze and make predictions about the impact on populations of geographic locales due to diseases, birth and death rates, urbanization, and natural events such as migration and seasonal changes.

FE061DB9DA05407182DD1ADEB521266F.description: analyze and predict the effects of non-renewable resource depletion;

11381D84146A409C8931AE3491FA4509.description: calculate birth rates and exponential growth of populations;

62EDF70013C74A0D8F2C28319B07F619.description: relate carrying capacity to population dynamics;

912F00E550C94E60A87B990C8CF58EE8.description: Science concepts. The student knows the relationship between carrying capacity and changes in populations and ecosystems. The student is expected to:

DB0876745D604535BE20A70EDC0543BF.description: investigate and identify energy interactions in an ecosystem.

F6E08440DAAA4CEB8E8959761E2B590A.description: investigate and explain the effects of energy transformations in terms of the laws of thermodynamics within an ecosystem;

589A45D63F1F4E38B7EB983D0248BB1A.description: explain the flow of energy in an ecosystem, including conduction, convection, and radiation;

31C0371A1F98400CA7F24456C3361B67.description: describe and compare renewable and non-renewable energy derived from natural and alternative sources such as oil, natural gas, coal, nuclear, solar, geothermal, hydroelectric, and wind;

C05CD8569D2D4B15A803470D8194813B.description: define and identify the components of the geosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere, atmosphere, and biosphere and the interactions among them;

8A0B3E2CF92D4205BBAED72BE8DBE794.description: Science concepts. The student knows the sources and flow of energy through an environmental system. The student is expected to:

93E9F9C9696B47F49D9AE2379A1C811F.description: evaluate the impact of waste management methods such as reduction, reuse, recycling, and composting on resource availability.

4AC5FC5BF7D343B09B2DE944028F847A.description: analyze and evaluate the economic significance and interdependence of resources within the environmental system;

271F543E2B4949CF8B702717FD79297F.description: identify renewable and non-renewable resources that must come from outside an ecosystem such as food, water, lumber, and energy;

C74520C10ABA4B0DBE4A3F9C8E7CA692.description: document the use and conservation of both renewable and non-renewable resources as they pertain to sustainability;

BC18B490A7B24B93B5F07AEEB8A040DE.description: identify source, use, quality, management, and conservation of water;

3BEC46E7B8AB4DEDADBB046ED93B4848.description: summarize methods of land use and management and describe its effects on land fertility;

FC803AED35244C0E9915FDD9C66E6883.description: Science concepts. The student knows the interrelationships among the resources within the local environmental system. The student is expected to:

FCEC7BEA10BF4399ADF2FF656B11161F.description: research and explain the causes of species diversity and predict changes that may occur in an ecosystem if species and genetic diversity is increased or reduced.

4A291FFAB68D4DEF91F0097EB3938EF8.description: predict how species extinction may alter the food chain and affect existing populations in an ecosystem;

08BA4DA1C8C74550AA4896490F7AB7E1.description: predict how the introduction or removal of an invasive species may alter the food chain and affect existing populations in an ecosystem;

774C089CF1174E07A45A7F387FB45D32.description: measure the concentration of solute, solvent, and solubility of dissolved substances such as dissolved oxygen, chlorides, and nitrates and describe their impact on an ecosystem;

6C7926600D374272873D3714156E7C33.description: make observations and compile data about fluctuations in abiotic cycles and evaluate the effects of abiotic factors on local ecosystems and local biomes;

C94A3C9F12884FE9B5FDB1E690EA7CD8.description: diagram abiotic cycles, including the rock, hydrologic, carbon, and nitrogen cycles;

0D866101289241C38D6CF7FDC2316B86.description: assess the role of native plants and animals within a local ecosystem and compare them to plants and animals in ecosystems within four other biomes;

751863557D61435590F831C552C40DBA.description: identify native plants and animals using a dichotomous key;

DCAF829E52104988B9402A81072D2F46.description: Science concepts. The student knows the relationships of biotic and abiotic factors within habitats, ecosystems, and biomes. The student is expected to:

8132D4FAB3D34F3199BBC62F76E358A8.description: research and describe the history of environmental science and contributions of scientists.

47FD8507ABF0431095DF322D28DE72F0.description: describe the connection between environmental science and future careers;

E9B9C5A853474C1193CB65569FA00F47.description: evaluate the impact of research on scientific thought, society, and the environment;

31794BEC54B345AD98AE9532E1A55281.description: draw inferences based on data related to promotional materials for products and services;

B8B231302D9E43EE8C85A29F72B58AE4.description: communicate and apply scientific information extracted from various sources such as current events, news reports, published journal articles, and marketing materials;

BBB69E76802B4CA9BE3A0C668A51005D.description: in all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student;

66B9FD3D19A04EE0A459FAA13C67ED4A.description: Scientific processes. The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions within and outside the classroom. The student is expected to:

B7CE481A8E0543E29931E9F3E4A07EF8.description: communicate valid conclusions supported by the data through methods such as lab reports, labeled drawings, graphic organizers, journals, summaries, oral reports, and technology-based reports.

4975C60C35B54DA398F9A5C6C63C74E1.description: perform calculations using dimensional analysis, significant digits, and scientific notation;

FF3447A47B47453E9D3A016624F76C9A.description: organize, analyze, evaluate, build models, make inferences, and predict trends from data;

891E6CDE54654B489E6F86BFD6299F4E.description: use a wide variety of additional course apparatuses, equipment, techniques, materials, and procedures as appropriate such as air quality testing devices, cameras, flow meters, Global Positioning System (GPS) units, Geographic Information System (GIS) software, computer models, densiometers, clinometers, and field journals;

19D301E52D724417B9E3110D77B8BA89.description: demonstrate the use of course apparatuses, equipment, techniques, and procedures, including meter sticks, rulers, pipettes, graduated cylinders, triple beam balances, timing devices, pH meters or probes, thermometers, calculators, computers, Internet access, turbidity testing devices, hand magnifiers, work and disposable gloves, compasses, first aid kits, binoculars, field guides, water quality test kits or probes, soil test kits or probes, 100-foot appraiser's tapes, tarps, shovels, trowels, screens, buckets, and rock and mineral samples;

837034BFB85B4C86ACBC5D0D4C341F09.description: collect data individually or collaboratively, make measurements with precision and accuracy, record values using appropriate units, and calculate statistically relevant quantities to describe data, including mean, median, and range;

6EA1E4D114304FA9AD39C8E50151B2AC.description: follow or plan and implement investigative procedures, including making observations, asking questions, formulating testable hypotheses, and selecting equipment and technology;

AA5E39BF24554BFC8B995EF79881611A.description: distinguish between scientific hypotheses and scientific theories;

11A9BB014A6E4A2FA7CF804411F8BFBC.description: know that scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well-established and highly-reliable explanations, but may be subject to change as new areas of science and new technologies are developed;

04175D9ECF744674AA23708A768C5CC4.description: know that scientific hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory power which have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into theories;

4E92711C5FF24AEFA0467800E98B57A1.description: know the definition of science and understand that it has limitations, as specified in subsection (b)(2) of this section;

A0E5D1A90E5C48D0ABF29FAF6A1C5A65.description: Scientific processes. The student uses scientific methods during laboratory and field investigations. The student is expected to:

FF30E3D59A69446188EEEC72203670A3.description: demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper disposal or recycling of materials.

C460E04BEEAC49848BDCE33CEB4F04A5.description: demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations, including appropriate first aid responses to accidents that could occur in the field such as insect stings, animal bites, overheating, sprains, and breaks;

F51102FD767448F285F46C3963A9ABEA.description: Scientific processes. The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, conducts hands-on laboratory and field investigations using safe, environmentally appropriate, and ethical practices. The student is expected to:

7C43AB593CD44DF39AC41EC20F33625D.description: Scientific systems. A system is a collection of cycles, structures, and processes that interact. All systems have basic properties that can be described in terms of space, time, energy, and matter. Change and constancy occur in systems as patterns and can be observed, measured, and modeled. These patterns help to make predictions that can be scientifically tested. Students should analyze a system in terms of its components and how these components relate to each other, to the whole, and to the external environment.

2548E54D6FA34054A57705C12855F654.description: Science and social ethics. Scientific decision making is a way of answering questions about the natural world. Students should be able to distinguish between scientific decision-making methods and ethical and social decisions that involve the application of scientific information.

32F0114710DE4C6197CB25EF1CFA4FE2.description: Scientific inquiry. Scientific inquiry is the planned and deliberate investigation of the natural world. Scientific methods of investigation can be experimental, descriptive, or comparative. The method chosen should be appropriate to the question being asked.

5381E1407B6B437E81D0BCCF6D9404E8.description: Nature of science. Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not scientifically testable.

EE72CA0C7948449A93415A7F789E7401.description: Environmental Systems. In Environmental Systems, students conduct laboratory and field investigations, use scientific methods during investigations, and make informed decisions using critical thinking and scientific problem solving. Students study a variety of topics that include: biotic and abiotic factors in habitats, ecosystems and biomes, interrelationships among resources and an environmental system, sources and flow of energy through an environmental system, relationship between carrying capacity and changes in populations and ecosystems, and changes in environments.

FE87531B643849F8B9EC76E4DBA3492B.description: General requirements. Students shall be awarded one credit for successful completion of this course. Suggested prerequisite: one unit high school life science and one unit of high school physical science. This course is recommended for students in Grade 11 or 12.
